summary: A letter from U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta (via an Assistant U.S. Attorney) to the Florida Bar Ethics Counsel requesting a written opinion on whether contacting victims of Jeffrey Epstein about the Non-Prosecution Agreement and the appointment of attorney-representative Robert Josefsberg violates Florida Bar rules. The letter describes the terms of the Epstein NPA and the process for victim notification.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: Signatory of the letter requesting an ethics opinion from the Florida Bar regarding victim contact procedures in the Jeffrey Epstein case. He is the United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida.

persons.name: Robert Josefsberg
persons.context: Selected by a Special Master (a former Chief U.S. District Judge) to serve pro bono as the independent attorney-representative for Epstein's victims, to advise them of their rights under the Non-Prosecution Agreement. His firm is Podhurst Orseck.

connections.description: Acosta's office (via the AUSA) is coordinating with Josefsberg regarding victim notification and representation under the Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement. Acosta's letter mentions Josefsberg will contact victims.

events.title: Ethics Opinion Request Filed
events.description: U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta submits a confidential request to the Florida Bar Ethics Counsel for guidance on victim contact procedures related to the Jeffrey Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: Signing of Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Prior to this letter, the U.S. Attorney's Office entered into a pre-indictment Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein. The agreement required Epstein to plead guilty to state offenses, register as a sex offender, waive challenges to civil liability under 18 U.S.C. ยง 2255, and pay for an independent attorney-representative for victims.

events.title: Appointment of Attorney-Representative
events.description: A former Chief U.S. District Judge, serving as a Special Master, selected Robert Josefsberg and his firm to serve as the independent attorney-representative for Epstein's victims under the terms of the NPA.

keyFacts: The document confirms the existence and key terms of a confidential Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) between the U.S. Attorney's Office and Jeffrey Epstein, requiring a guilty plea to state charges and victim compensation.

The U.S. Attorney's Office, led by R. Alexander Acosta, included a term in the NPA requiring Epstein to pay for an independent attorney (Robert Josefsberg) to advise victims of their rights, notably their right to sue under 18 U.S.C. ยง 2255 for a minimum of $150,000.
An attorney for one victim has accused both the AUSA and Robert Josefsberg of violating Florida Bar Rule 4-7.4 (concerning solicitation) by contacting victims directly, prompting this ethics inquiry.

The letter reveals the U.S. Attorney's Office was notifying victims of the NPA's resolution and Josefsberg's appointment, but had to modify procedures for victims who had already retained civil counsel.
The document is marked 'CONFIDENTIAL' and explicitly states it relates to a confidential Non-Prosecution Agreement, highlighting the sensitive nature of the Epstein plea deal.
